								When I start up this game, I see a really blurry picture of a guy who looks like Gordon Freeman holding a hatchet.  Then when I press start I'm dropped into the middle of some sort of desert/forest/lake area.  There's a short loop of a wind sound playing.  My character is holding his hand out like he's got a gun, but he doesn't.  There's a flashlight shining magically in front of me from out of nowhere.  As I clumsily climb a nearby hill through an obscene amount of motion blur I see a building in the distance but assume it's part of a flat skybox graphic because the depth of field is horrible and everything is deliberately out of focus.  As I head towards it I realize it is actually real.  I hear a weird noise as I cross a lake, then notice spider arms to the left and right of the screen as my life meter slowly drops.  I turn around but keep running backwards.  I see a giant...thing.  Maybe a spider?  Or a crayfish?  Can't be sure, but eventually it quits trying to softly hug me to death and runs away sideways for no reason at all.  After a long boring walk, I finally make it to the buildings.  I find a gun, and after much frustration realize I can pick it up by pressing E on my keyboard (no button on my Xbox 360 controller will do it).  A moment later everything freezes for a few seconds while the game loads up some music and an army of identical black zombies in orange jumpsuits.  As they slide unnaturally around the stage I shoot them and they begin to flop all over the place, stretching and morphing like blobs of silly putty.  Sometimes another spider-crayfish shows up and tries to hug me some more.  Sometimes one will shoot a fireball the size of a truck at me, and my graphics suddenly choke so bad I beg for the slip-sliding army of incompetent zombie clones and spider-crayfish to end my life.  Finally it happens and I quit.I do not understand what I've just experienced.  I got this game for free in some bundle, but somehow I still feel ripped off.

This. So much this. Imagine the martians are PanzerGamingStudios and the computer is Unreal 4 and you have a clear idea of what's going on here.Read ahead if you like, but you shouldn't have to. It's that bad.Furthermore, on account of the fact that the developer's page doesn't have any emblems or information about their label, a link to website, anything to indicate that it's Panzer Gaming Studios other than the name panzergamingstudios, I don't trust them. I trust them less because the Store page shows some screenshots that are from the Unreal Engine 4 editor, not from the game. EDIT: PanzerGamingStudios clearly has never heard of the Streisand Effect, as his attempts to delete, ban, lock and otherwise suppress the DELUGE of negative press has only succeeded in... well... generating even more damning negative press.The glaring issues with the game are as follows;-It is NOT FUN.-No 64 bit mode, which may help it's framerate some.-No Steamworks integration. Collector's cards work, but that's about it. You cannot take screenshots or access the overlay from within the game, on account of a DOS-based go-between program to launch the game. Nor does Print Screen take screen captures. It only captures a black screen. You literally need to have a very good third party video or screenshot application to be able to take ANYTHING you see in the game out of it.-Abysmal optimisation. Even on powerful current gen hardware the game lags horribly. The scripted in-engine introduction sequence has a framerate around 10FPS.-Even with it's horrid framerate, it is ugly as sin. You'd think that a game that drags your framerate down into the 10-20 range would be approaching photorealism, but this game is just... there are better looking games in Unreal 2. This game is built in Unreal 4. Just... yeah.-Mouselook arbitrarily stops responding for 1-3 seconds at a time.-Horrible screen and texture tearing.-The camera sometimes floats 'inside' the character, so you're looking through their arm.-Nonsensical writing. It might make more sense if a paranoid schitzophrenic had written it.-Braindead AI. The developer has attempted to hide the fact that the AI is beyond stupid by giving them way too much HP and hit way too hard, giving them game sort of artificial difficulty. The enemies are still as dumb as a bag of hammers and COULD be kited indefinitely. EDIT: You do not even need to fight the enemies. You can simply run past them to get to the next level.-Broken maps, repetative and unimaginative set pieces.-Special effects so bright as to be blinding.-The game is constantly changing. And by changing I don't mean mechanical tweaks, extra mobs, balancing, etc. The very layout of the game changes, as well as the combat system. It does not seem like the developer has any idea what they want the game to be. -The game locks up without warning to load. The developer informed me that this is a flaw in the design of all iterations of Unreal, but that there are ways to make it less glaring. None of which are being implemented. To be honest, with the exception of Space Marine I can't ever recall a video game built in Unreal locking up without warning to load the next area.-The music, while upbeat, is repetative and at times downright irritating to the point I mute the game.-Other sound effects are derivative, possibly even stock Unreal assets and annoying.-Broken magic system. Seriously, the game's unskippable introduction explains the magic system, but magic right now is completely unusable.-The single instance of voice acting in the game is terribly done. He might have been able to record better audio with a camcorder or iPhone. No really. It's THAT bad. You can even hear the mouse click when he began recording. That's how few f*cks he gave about it.-The one NPC in the game barely moves, and during the horrid voice acting his face does not even move, nevermind have any kind of lip syncing.-I'm pretty sure that the monster at the beginning of the game is directly ripped off from DOOM. (Hell Knight and Cyberdemon look EXTREMELY familiar, eh?)TL;DR - Calling this game Alpha build is a total lie. On account of it's handful of working maps that are constantly changing in design and layout, combat system in a constant state of being reworked, and overall being unplayable I would be extremely hard pressed to say that it is past pre-alpha, maybe even still in preproduction. It may have, at one point been a decent game when it was in UDK. But since having been rebuilt completely from the ground up in UE4, it's a disaster. This game does not belong on Steam. Also;Awards1st Place Winner for Best Indie Game at Whitewater MAGD Awards (2013) 2nd Place Winner for Best Indie Game at Whitewater MAGD Awards (2012)I recant my initial statement about this. Instead I submit that it is a complete lie. http://i.imgur.com/BgTDLZq.pngThis thread has since been deleted by the developer. An action that both proves my point in the reply, and compounds my lack of faith in him and his project.The developer himself admits that the game that recieved these awards was A New Reckoning - UDK. 												Its rare when I get to review a game five times in the span of two years, but Time Ramesside continues to be one the most absurd oddity I've ever come across. Time Ramesside is a horrible first person shooter first and foremost, but each and every iteration is different. Every update has a new start level and after spending more than twelve hours in the game and making extensive bug reports to the developers, I've still never once completed any of the dozen first levels that I've played.This version is completely different than the last version I played two months ago. The game has been completed and finished for half a year now, but it continues to be worked on. Time Ramesside has gotten better yes, but for every step forward it takes a huge leap back and breaks its legs. Now that the game is finished its been announced this was only the first episode. I have a feeling that's their way of cutting the game into thirds without finishing it.The last version I played started me off with an extremely long cut scene after another cut scene and on top of that was another cut scene. My player fell out of a small prison bus and made his way into a prison dodging cameras that would close the doors if he was spotted. Its odd that trying to get into a prison would close giant gates, but whatever. Why question the logic? The structures hovered above ground, but nothing was as bad as the spawning arachnids that could kill the player easy and spawn in right on top of him.Oh but this current update has you in front of a prison on a bridge, but now its a warmer setting. The ground is covered with shallow pools of water and there is grass overtaking everything. Its abandon except for the flesh less zombies inside.the yard. These zombies spawn in mid air on top of one another so one can be hovering over a cluster of other zombies. This is nothing new. The animations look strange and stiff, but I suppose its better than the T pose they originally had.That's one of the downfalls of releasing a game too early to the public. We get a chance to remember and sour future reviews. The developers would listen to constructive feedback and act like they'd do something about it, but at the end of the day when they put "resolved" on a bug in the forum it was never resolved so much as acknowledged yes this is a bug.The controls are awful. Rather than typical strafe with the left and right, you're forced to turn with the left and right as if its the mid nineties all over again. Its quite a tease having rebindable keys that save, but you're still stuck with the default control scheme. There are also two different sections to rebind your keys when there only needs to be one. That's how flawed the game is when there are so many problems with the menus.As you walk on the long bridge from a wrecked semmi into the prison you're greeted with floating text blurbs instructing you how to play. How to pick up weapons, use spells and hop into a wormhole for health. It just looks awkward having the floating prompts light signs rather than on your heads up display. This heads up display I should mention looks a lot better than it did before, which originally was drawn text and ugly simple shapes.As a game, Time Ramesside is just dull. There are zombies and arachnids to shoot, but the real game here is playing spot the issues. Such as weapons to pick up that have blue boxes around them, but the blue boxes are facing a different way than the weapon. Tires that are in pavement and walls that hover in the air. There are also invisible walls blocking obvious doorways.One plus is that the needlessly long cut scenes have been removed. Perhaps they were just moved further into the game. I'd much rather have a game to play than get lost in the cut scenes.Time Ramesside is also a game known for its stock assets and I have no problem with that, but just make a good game to compensate for it. You can make something good, get money for it and then add custom models, textures and everything afterward. All I want is an enjoyable game I can play, but this is at the bottom of the barrel. There is no program icon to the game and its still known as "shootergame-win-32-shipping." That alone is a testament to the quality you're getting.Another thing that makes this game an unyielding beast is the file size compared to what you get with the game. Its just a far too huge game for the low quality of its assets. Even with the highest settings it looks sub par for the large file size. That's the fault of the high quality engine though as is the texture pop in. When larger developers struggle with the same thing its tough to hold that against Time Ramesside.I've seen this project for far too long and while it has gotten marginally better over the past six months, its still a horrible game. I doubt the developers have the talent to make it any better than it is. However, they do seem determined to keep pressing on, so that's always a positive. The only catch now is they're pressing on with the second episode of a game so bad it should be legendary if only it was better to be legendarily bad. Does that even make sense?There's no flair, passion or zest here. Even with a completed game it was still dead on arrival to an angry mob. A second episode will only yield the same results. The developers will make a great looking trailer of footage that I'll be unable to find in the game when I play it.

												Edit 2: (2/4/2016)I'll give the dev credit where it's due: the game's better. But at the cost of the whole story. Everything has changed. Literally every, last, thing has changed. No powers, no bus in the middle of a winter storm, no guy randomly punching you and walking out; the story changed completely... but the game still isn't worth your money.Edit:Since writing this, I have played the game more and my opinion remains the same. The game lacks a lot of animations, there are many bugs regarding AI, the control scheme still needs to be ironed out, and just in its entirety the game needs a ton of improvement before it can be considered market-ready.- - - - - - - - - - -First off, I did not play this game for more than 10 minutes. That's because half of the time was spent sitting through a black intro screen that cannot be skipped (which apparently is due to an issue with Unreal Engine), and the rest of the time was spent running around with a knife held as though a rifle was in its place.The game starts you off, upon launching the game, with a small command prompt box. No complaint there, if it has to be there then it has to be there. Then it opens the actual game menu window. This menu window's "options" button did not work, so I couldn't go to full screen from there. No biggie. Press new game and now you wait through the aforementioned intro. When it's finally over, you "wake up" (I don't know what led to the protagonist being dropped off there) in a prison/dungeon of some sort with a crossbow at your feet.Pressing esc gives you one type of game menu. Pressing Q gives you an alternate game menu. Both have different options inside of them, so that's really weird by itself. In neither can you change your keybindings, so whatever the developer has set is what you're stuck with. Speaking of the keybindings, there is no tutorial (to my knowledge) on what the controls are. Instead, you have to awkwardly walk up to the aforementioned crossbow and ask yourself how to pick it up. Only to fail to even accomplish that task, since after pressing all buttons on my keyboard and mouse, I failed to do even that.I figured maybe it's just a prop and can't actually be used, so instead, I ran with this knife being held oddly like a rifle and for every enemy I ran into, this annoying whispered "I'm going to kill you" was sounded. There's more to mention, like how crouching does nothing except change the positioning of your camera so you can see your own character's textures, and how the enemies don't seem to hurt you unless they align themselves perfectly to really get the damage done, and how the animations are minimal at best. However, I think with the other reviews and everything else considered, the point is clear.Don't release unfinished games. At the very least, get the HUD finished and the basic features ironed out. This game is truly not ready for the market. Fortunately, I only got it in a bundle, so it wasn't much of a bite from my wallet.Oh, and changing the game's name is definitely suspect.

												If, like me, you're a fan of the FPS genre of games, you'd think Time Ramesside is a worthy investment - it's not.   I don't like having to unrecommend an FPS game with a promising premise, but this game has far too many lazy technical and gameplay problems.Sure, you have a few graphics settings - but they're clumsy - you can't turn off motion blur, instead, you have to click "low->medium->high->epic" on the settings and guess at which one might turn it off.   It does work well enough in 4K, but that's not the problem.The developer was simply too lazy to "finish" the game.  Some scenes in the game look great!  And others look like utter crap - fuzzy textures on incomplete models clashing with highly polished jail cells and nice lighting effects.   What we're seeing here might well be the effect of introducing the developers to crystal meth halfway through the development cycle, which might explain the jekyll & hyde levels of quality and shabbiness.  You even have clipping issues when reloading your gun - jaggy polygons seen through your partially-invisible arm!Gameplay is equally and inexplicably shoddy - it's the same effectively as 1996's Quake, from iD software (it's 2016 now).   You can run, jump, look up, look down, run over piles of bullets left around on the ground.   You fight some nicely modelled zombie things which disappear as soon as you shoot them!  I guess they spent the "develop a lying down corpse" budget on more crystal meth.   For some reason, in the first level, you're in some kind of jail/mental asylum full of zombies.  The cell block is around as big as New York City, which is weird, and not really much fun running around in this endless single path full of the same game assets again and again.So, all in all, this might look great but it's not, it's awful.

Early Access Review
								I do not like this game.  I've tried, but something is wrong when the tutorial level has enemies with WAY too much health.  A tutorial level should help the player get adjusted to the game, and, in a sense, I suppose ANR's (A New Reckoning) tutorial level is no different.  You start by phasing through a bus door, the bus is surrounded by police cars, (which are not to appropriate scale to the character), and are greeted by floating text blocks which give you a run down how to select the 'teleport' spell and use it.  As of this writing, the UI is little more than text (I hope they get a rudimentary iconic UI up soon, as the text is dull and quite ugly, maybe a spell selection wheel with spells that are not available grey'd out.)After learning to teleport, you are invited into a building that opens the way to the rest of the map.  It is largely a walking simulator at this point, where you can marvel at indoor street lamps (the kind you see on the streets, generally not indoors), snow on the floor (though it has no way to get there), and some bushes curiously growing out of the snow.  After teleporting to the other side of a fence, I am attacked by a demon-thingy.  Simple affair, bullets, death, move on.After destroying the demon dog thingy, I am then accosted by a flaming spider of significant size.  As I fight it, it poops out smaller, not flaming spiders every time it teleports near me.  If you ignore the smaller spiders, they become a life syphon, and eat all your health.  I found myself unloading an entire clip just to get rid of one of the spiders.  Circle strafing and typical FPS skills don't count here, as the baby spiders stick to you like glue.  I died.  Quick.Trying again, I teleported up to the rafters in the building, so while the baby spiders couldn't reach me, I couldn't get any health pickups, and quickly ran out of ammo and spell juice.  I lobbed a couple fireballs at them, taking down two or three at a time, only to have flaming titan spider pop back next to me and poop out more.  I dropped back to the ground, and picked up the health pickups, and ammo, and was swarmed.  I died.  Again.  On a tutorial level.  No matter HOW GOOd or BAD a player is, they should NEVER fail on a tutorial level.  And if they do fail, they should be allowed to try whatever they are trying to do again, without having to be dropped back to the intro screen, or text, or whatever.Right now, the game plays like a bare bones Unreal game, without, well, the fun.  If you are thinking about getting this game, I would suggest not, but if you do, at least wait until:1.)  It's closer to completion2.)  It's on sale for really, really, really cheapor3.)  Know what you are getting yourself into.It's not good, even for early access, not at this point, anyway.  And believe me, I am a huge Early Access supporter.  I have many Early Access titles.  The congative dissonance I've witnessed from the developer in the forums (like those who do not like the game being called "trolls") is another turn off for me, and reminds me of a great quote I once read:"If one person has a problem with you, it's likely their fault.  If two people have a problem with you, I can still give you the benefit of the doubt.  But if three or more people have a problem with you, the problem probably lies with you."A vast majority of the reviews, even for an early access game, seem pretty negative for this title.  Many games that are early access, if their supporters see potential in the game, regardless of the bugs or lack of polish (Look at The Forest, or Dead State, or Dungeon of the Endless, or 7 Days to Die, etc etc) they will still net largely positive reviews.  That says something, doesn't it?

												*I did not pay for this game. I got it free through a give away.*This is a re-review after 2 major updates. I just wanted to do this out of fairness. This review contains spoilers. So here we go:This game is not even remotely what it used to be. In fact it now looks like it's trying to be a horror game. Everything is different for the most part and the only way to talk about this game is by level.Level 1 - IntroductionThis is basically a level where you fight a bunch of monsters while the credits go by. You're trapped in a prison with a bunch of monsters and a little girl.Pros-Great atmosphere.Cons-The flashlight is located behind your machine gun causing a ton of glare on the front sight.-It's confusing as what you're supposed to do.-Shooting monsters is not fun as they don't hurt you, can trap you, and their death animation restarts every time you shoot them causing you to waste a ton of ammo.-The little girl has no point and you can clip through her.Level 2 - Prison LevelHere you start 10 minutes before the introduction. It's like the intro but now you aren't trapped.Pros-Great atmosphere again-There's a story.-There's decent voice work.Cons-There's no reason to shoot anything and you can run past everything.-Shooting stuff still isn't fun.-There's a hallway that looks spooky but when you go down it you realize it's actually a missing wall that takes you outside of the map.-Doors are broken. If you go up to a door and it opens go through it because if it closes you're never opening it up again.-Nothing is scary as the jump scares are cartoony compared to the rest of the environment, not sudden, and too far away.-It ends abruptly in a confusing way.Level 3 - Outside city areaYou're now outside on the city streets. I'm assuming because you escaped the prison even though it's not entirely clear.Pros-Impressive variety of new monsters that, even though they're stock, fit quite well.-Lighting is nice and you can see where you're going.-Ammo is available on the ground.-There's a cool looking boss at the end.Cons-Again there's no point to shooting things and there's no reason to anyway since it's way too open.-Because of the above this level is extremely boring.-There's no point to the boss fight as you can run past and end the level.Level 4 - Condemned buildingThis time you're in an abandoned building. This is by far the best level in the game.Pros-Excellent atmosphere-The hallway is narrower so you have a reason to shoot things.-There are open rooms that hold spooky set pieces.-Far more effort and planning then previous levels.Cons-Shooting is still not fun due to animations getting restarted when you shoot as things are dying.-I didn't want to go into some of the side rooms because I didn't want to accidently break the game again and have to start over.-The ending is kind of bad and makes no sense at all.Overall OpinionEven though this game is now actually playable I still wouldn't recommend paying for it. It's currently at a pre-alpha state and $10 is a huge rip off. It's not what I'd call "fun" and still needs a ton of work. It's also really unoptimized so expect slowdowns like crazy in some spots. Level transitions are terrible as well and in some instances I wasn't sure if I was going to the next level or if the game froze on me.That being said, the dev is going in the right direction with it and I'm really happy to see regular updates. I either died or got to the end of the game (I went down the hallway to the right) so I can't comment on if there's anything past level 4 as of yet. I'm putting it down as recommended only because it looks like Panzer Gaming Studios is trying to turn it into something and because I support indi devs.

Early Access Review
								---Let me describe my experiences with each boot. Keep in mind I am completely aware that this is an early alpha, and I'm loving every moment of this adventure. **not sarcasm...seriously**1: The first time I played this (back when it first got on steam), there was a cinematic with a bus ride, the bus exploded or something, and the game began. I walked into a city like environment, with a couple different guns, each with pretty descent looking particle effects, and tons of giant spiders coming at me. Clearly early alpha, but seemed like a good start. There was an actual hud, and what seemed like descent horde-like gameplay (reminded me a bit of a poor mans Pain Killer). I'll give it time come back to it a few months later...see how it progressed.2: I heard that Jim Sterling did a video on this. This was just a couple weeks ago. During Jims video you see a now stationary bus, with a guy on fire. The camera pans out of the bus, as if someone shoved the camera out of the back window of the bus, and the camera fell into the snow on its side. It or you stands back up, and you're in game. this time another snowy area, but with garages, some generic buildings, chain link fences, and some mismatched floors. After some walking, some zombies chased at him, then some spiders, and then a big spider who really liked to hump a rock. That was pretty much about it, no end of level, unless you count falling out of the level. I do not.3: So after watching Jims video I decide to boot it up again. This Time I'm greeted with something completely different. I'm seemingly inside one of the Bus garages from the Sterling video, but now its more of a super dark train station, with clippable trains. But there's some actual gameplay...sort of. I'm quickly greeted by dozens if not hundreds of zombies, demons, hospital gowned children, all running at me...then running past me. "OOOKIE", I thought to myself. Now I'm running and running past these guys, make my way out of the bus station, and meet up with a bunch of soldiers statically shooting handguns..sort of (the hands move, but the guns didn't). That was the end of the level. Next level seems to take me into a subway, which kept would just crash and took me back to the title screen. I hit continue ans I started back at the begginning again. ALT F4...try again later.4: I see another update for the game hit steam. Let's see if it's a different game this time! YUP! I start off in that Subway like level, the previous cityscape, bus, train station, and soldier all gone. Now I'm in a subway, and the game has a pretty cool opening which matched the design of this level. The HUD is missing though and replaced with just numbers and ugly boxes. But this time it's almost playable. The first level is pretty descent making my way around this subway like area, maybe a basement to a building, I'm not sure, but there's garbage EVERYWHERE! Tons and tons of garbage bags litter the place, but there's stuff to shoot, ammo to pick up, spells to cast, time to slow down, it's almost a functioning game. It was terrible, but I was almost having a good time (but I like bad things)...I even streamed it. The first level had an opening sequence with what seemed to be an actual story attempting to take place. I made my way through the first level, and started the second level. The game had new enemies, and this creepy guy who whispered loudly, "I WILL KILL YOU" ...actually kind of creeped me out a bit.   By the third level, I exit the the subway like area, and I'm now on top of a building. Demons all over, so I'm making my way through what seems to be an empty waiting line for a six flags ride, and come upon an elevator, that led down. I hop on the elevator, and it takes me to a storage room full of barrels and a giant door, door won't open, nothing to trigger the end of the level. That was that, but hey it was progress with about 45 minutes worth of glitchy but semi fun gameplay. 5: Tonight, I see ANOTHER UPDATE! I'm like, "I wonder if it's gonna be different again?". I boot up the game. Same descent opening cinematic. But then it drops me back into the Sterling version of the game. WTF. All the goodness of the previous build...GONE. The snow field with the bus, fences and spiders back in full effect, only this time, the floors matched up,  there was a guy standing outside telling me how to cast spells and that I'd gain magic by running, which is good because I only got 24 bullets to use on the spiders that attacked me... But guess what...the spells did no damage and niether did the bullets. After some walking forward, a giant spider attacked and then the game just reset me to the title screen. WTF? ROFL!---After all this, I have to wonder to myself, did this "game" get put on steam because the games developer was a Valve employees autistic little cousin? "Is this "game" just a MASSIVE TROLL in disguise? Is this "game" a creation of a madman who restarts from scratch on every new build? Is this "game" social commentary on the state on Steams greenlight and Early Access? Is this "game" just a guy messing around with the Unreal 4 engine with no clear direction? I Reckon I have no idea, but I bet the next time I boot this game, it's gonna be yet again "A NEW RECKONING"

								Tazer Gaming Community Review/ KimSo this is going be a tricky review to make since I'm making one on a game that doesn’t really have much more then potential to it at the moment. The game in question in A New Reckoning by a company called Panzer Gaming Studios. The game itself is about….well I don’t know cause it does not have a story as of yet, nor any named characters for that matter making it hard for me to find something to talk about in the way of story and characters (obviously). So what I'm going to do is talk about the POTENTIAL the game has, and some thing's I can see improvements in. For that I took a closer look at the developers behind the game, Panzer Gaming Studios. And there was not much to tell at all, what I did find out was that the game was a kick starter project and not much else. The game itself is as I sad so far without a story to it so I can't tell you what it is about, alien invasion some kind of virus, or maybe just some dude at a Justin Bieber concert, that would explain all the hell demons on earth and why you wake up in prison.  Who knows at this stage, what I can tell you though, is that it is moving forward as far as developing is concerned. When I first got into the game you started in the great outdoors. There appeared to be zombies roaming around (or skateboarding as their legs weren't always moving) some plant monsters and the occasional bug monster. And you had a flashlight…..yes that was it. You where supposed to hold a gun I was sure because of the way one held one’s hands. But no gun was visible and no ammo either. Best I could do was to run around yelling "bang bang" in the hopes all my enemies would be very dodgy on the heart. The game was totally broken, my enemies and I would continually fall through the world as the ground broke, waterfalls that ended in nowhere and lakes that were just as hard as the rock around them. Since then however it has developed to at least four levels (at the time of writing) maybe more but that’s as far as I could go, less skating zombies, a new enemy type and 3 different weapons and ammo. It's come a long way, and I hope it will continue down this road. But I also see a lot if disinformation around this game. But more about this later, let's start with the game. When you start the game you break out from your cell by bashing a zombies head in during a very simple cut scene. Still I liked that it was there. I don’t know if this is the real beginning of the game, but for now, this is what it is. You then get to make your through an almost maze like surroundings as you try to find your way out. You will encounter zombies, and in many cases a lot of them in 3 different forms, as well as a new demon enemy that I really like so far. Even though the animation for it is not yet complete I still think that it is a nice one and it brings the game from the common "zombie genre" to something else, maybe a demon invasion, or hell rift at some place. I don’t know the story of the game yet. But the demon is a nice addition to the game at this point. Among these enemies are a few bug ones as well, imagine an overgrown face-hugger from Aliens that mated with an ant or a mosquito without wings. I like them (except in level two, but I will leave the "why" up to you to find out) they need a bit of work though, especially the big one that serves as a boss in level one as it gets stuck in one place for most of the time, which obviously makes it really easy to kill. In the outdoor levels you also encounter a plant monster that too looked kind of cool. It does not move right but it should be nice when the game is ready for its release. Other than that, there are, as of now 3 weapons in the game as well; a normal assault rifle not a bad one but aiming down sights can sometimes cause the bullets to fly off in random directions; a shotgun that is all but good - The first shot from it will look like you shot a big flare and nothing else, It’s a big boom that only serves to blind the shooter himself and the second shot simply goes off with a poof to compensate for the solar flare it just threw in your face. My favourite of the 3 is the crossbow. Now the only way to make one of those better is explosive arrows, and what do you know...it has! Not only that, it also has some glowing mystical stuff that explodes. Not sure what it is, but it definitely explodes when it hits enemies and that’s half the battle right, making stuff explode. The levels themselves are so far very simple as far as walls, floors and ceilings go, but they do get better when you get outside. I just wish there were more levels outside as I found them more enjoyable to play (and I did not get lost either). They don’t have much in the way of decorations either, with just a few pipes and wot-nots, as well as a few corpses here and there, but it's not more than that. Still, it’s an alpha and I do see a lot of improvements from its earlier stages. Now there is not much else to the game at this point, but I did want to talk about some of the disinformation about the game. First off, the rumour that the game has been cancelled...nope, it was merely renamed as the developers went over to a new engine, now working in the UE4 engine instead of UDK. So the game is still up and running. Secondly there were people that thought themselves tricked as the game they bought into was nothing at all like the trailer that was shown on the games Steam page in the store. I can understand this in some ways but on the other hand people should have figured as the trailer was from the supposedly finished game, and not the alpha build we have now. I too was a bit "What the f**k is This?" and still, I knew it was an alpha game. As I said though they are moving forward with the game in the right direction and I’d also like to say that many of the things people complain about is mainly of what they believe is false advertisement of the game to come. For example there is a picture of what looks like a huge scorpion on the developer’s Facebook page that I so far have not seen in any of my game plays. I sympathize with the developers though, because it takes times to make a game, however, maybe one should be careful about what one posts and how one does it. Why not label it work in progress, and people will not have to feel fooled or tricked that they did not find it in the game. My final words for now about ‘A New Reckoning’, is that it has potential, and I would love to play the final product. And I really hope the developers keep working on this. Even though it's not there today I believe it will be in the future, I just hope it won't be too far in the future.  I will come back to this title at a later stage when it’s closer to release, but until then, happy gaming people.- By Kim Gustafsson
